metadata.title: Aging rheological characteristics of SBR modified asphalt with multi-dimensional nanomaterials

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Aging rheological characteristics of SBR modified asphalt with multidimensional nanomaterials
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2017.06.121 0950-0618/ 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author at: College of Civil Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha, China.
E-mail address: hlzhang@hnu.edu.cn (H. Zhang).
Chongzheng Zhu a, Henglong Zhang a,b,⇑, Guoqing Xu a, Caijun Shi a aCollege of Civil Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha, China b State Engineering Laboratory of Highway Maintenance Technology, Changsha University of Science & Technology, Changsha, China
h i g h l i g h t s
The rheological properties of SBRMA with nanomaterials are studied. The aging resistance of SBRMA can be improved by multi-dimensional nanomaterials. The recommended proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials is confirmed as 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 13 March 2017 Received in revised form 26 May 2017 Accepted 19 June 2017
Keywords: SBR modified asphalt Multi-dimensional nanomaterials Rheological properties Thermal oxidative aging Photo oxidative aging
a b s t r a c t
The purpose of this work is to research the influence of multi-dimensional nanomaterials composed of surface modified nano-zinc oxide (nano-ZnO) and organic expanded vermiculite (OEVMT) on rheological characteristics of styrene butadiene rubber modified asphalt (SBRMA) before and after different aging methods. The styrene butadiene rubber modified asphalts (SBRMAs) with various proportions multidimensional nanomaterials were produced by melt blending method. All binders were aged by rolling thin film oven test (RTFOT), pressure aging vessel (PAV) and ultraviolet (UV) aging. Dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) was utilized to test the rheological properties of all samples, as well as the performance grade (PG) of all binders was checked. The results show that the addition of multi-dimensional nanomaterials can enhance the shear deformation resistance and elastic behavior of SBRMA. Based on the RTFOT, PAV and UV aging test results, both thermal oxidative and photo oxidative aging resistance of SBRMA can be improved significantly by introducing multi-dimensional nanomaterials. Moreover, the optimal proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials in SBRMA is confirmed as 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO. Besides, the PG test result verifies that the PG of SBRMA after 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO modifying maintains unchanged.
2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, along with the rapid increasing of traffic volume and axle load, ordinary asphalt pavement has been unable to satisfy the traffic requirements due to serious premature failures occurring, such as rutting at high temperature, fatigue and low temperature cracking and aging [1]. Fortunately, the appearance of polymer modified asphalts greatly enhances pavement performances, which significantly facilitates the development of transportation [2]. Among them, styrene butadiene rubber (SBR) has been one of the most effective modifiers in improving asphalt properties,
especially low temperature performance, which contributes to the application of asphalt pavement in cold area [3].
However, for SBR modified asphalt (SBRMA), the poor storage stability between SBR and asphalt at high temperature and aging phenomenon all the same are problems demanding prompt solution. In particular for the latter, on the one hand, aging stiffens the asphalt phase in SBRMA, which in turn weakens the adhesion between asphalt and aggregate [4]. On the other hand, by reason of a mass of butadiene in the SBR molecule, SBR molecule is vulnerable to be oxidized undergoing aging [5], then the network composed of SBR and asphalt is destroyed [6,7]. Both two aspects would seriously cut down on the service life of SBRMA pavement. Therefore, some works have been conducted for addressing them. Some studies showed that adding nanoclay (eg. montmorillonite) into SBRMA may form an exfoliated structure, moreover, the high-temperature storage stability of SBRMA was improved [8–
10]. Besides, the introduction of nano-particles (eg. nano-CaCO3 particles) also could improve the compatibility between SBR and base asphalt [11]. In order to improve the ability of asphalt, SBR or SBRMA to resist aging, Zhang et al. [12] compared the influence of different layered silicates on aging performances of base asphalt, and draw a conclusion that modified asphalt containing OEVMT had better anti-aging performance than modified asphalt containing organic rectorite or organic montmorilionite. Additionally, Zhang et al. [13] further found that modified asphalt containing nano-ZnO had the better UV anti-aging ability than modified asphalt containing nano-silica or nano-titania. He et al. [14] demonstrated that the addition of nanoclay (sodiummontmorilionite) could enhance thermal aging resistance of SBR. Sun et al. [15] investigated that the influence of nano-materials and polymers composite on the high and low temperature performance of asphalt using orthogonal experiment design, and finally determined that the optimal modified asphalt formulas was 5% SiO2(nano-silica)+5%SBR + 1%PE(polyethylene). Moreover, the optimal modified asphalt showed a better aging resistance than base asphalt. Dessouky et al. [16] pointed out that the hindered phenol additives could retard the stiffening increase in SBRMA after RTFOT + PAV aging.
In accordance with our published studies, layered silicates only had clear improvement for thermal-oxidative aging resistance of asphalt, while inorganic nanoparticles merely showed significant enhancement for photo-oxidative aging resistance of asphalt [17–19]. In the paper, multi-dimensional nanomaterials as a novel anti-aging modifier made up of nano-particles of zero dimensional nanomaterials and layered silicates of two dimensional nanomaterials introduced into SBRMA is desirous to enhance both thermal oxidative and photo oxidative aging resistance of SBRMA.
Asphalt is a typical viscos-elastic materials, its rheological properties are close related to pavement performances. In the paper, dynamic shear rheological test was utilized to characterize viscos-elastic behavior of asphalt binder. Complex modulus (G⁄) and phase angle (d) are two important dynamic shear rheological parameters. G⁄ characterizes the ability of asphalt binder to resist shear deformation, while d reflects the ratio of viscos component to elastic component in asphalt binder.
The purpose of this work is to evaluate the influence of multidimensional nanomaterials containing nano-ZnO and OEVMT on rheological characteristics of SBRMA before and after aging. Various proportions multi-dimensional nanomaterials were selected for modifying SBRMA, different aging methods (eg. RTFOT, PAV and UV aging) and DSR tests were conducted on all binders, as well as the performance grade (PG) of all binders was checked. Finally, the optimal proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials in SBRMA was determined by overall considering all test results.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials
Base asphalt used in this study was 60/80 penetration grade. The basic properties such as penetration (25 C), softening point, ductility (15 C) and viscosity (135 C) are 63 dmm, 47.9 C, >150.0 cm and 437.5 mPa s, respectively. Cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) and expanded vermiculite (EVMT) were selected to prepare OEVMT according to the reference [18]. Nano-zinc oxide, 15– 25 nm, was surface modified using silane coupling agent. The silane coupling agent is c-(2,3-epoxypropoxy) propyltrimethoxysilane, analytical pure.
2.2. Preparation of multi-dimensional nanomaterials modified SBRMA
The multi-dimensional nanomaterials modified SBRMA were produced by melt blending method. At the first step, 3%SBR by mass of base asphalt was added in liquated base asphalt using a high shear mixer at 4000 rpm for 45 min, and the temperature kept at 150 ± 5 C, then the SBR modified asphalt (SBRMA) was obtained. At the second step, various proportions multi-dimensional nanomaterials, 2% nano-ZnO or 2%OEVMT were introduced into the SBRMA using a high shear mixer
at 4000 rpm for 60 min, the temperature maintained 150 ± 5 C, then the nanomaterials modified SBRMA was obtained. The SBRMA containing no nanomaterials was dealt with uniform process for obtaining the blank sample.
2.3. Rheological properties test
The rheological properties of all samples were tested by dynamic shear rheometer (DSR), which adopted temperature sweep mode in accordance with ASTM D 7175 [20]. The strain and frequency were controlled at 1% and 10 rad/s respectively, and the sweeping temperature ranges were from 30 to 90 C with an increment of 2 C/min. Complex modulus (G⁄) and phase angle (d) as important rheological parameters were utilized to analyze the rheological performances of all samples before and after aging. Performance grade (PG) of all binders was tested in accordance with AASHTO R 29 [21].
2.4. Aging procedures
In the study, RTFOT [22], PAV [23] and UV [24] aging test were performed for simulating the short term thermal oxidative, long term thermal oxidative and long term photo oxidative aging, respectively. The aging procedures conditions were as follows: RTFOT, 163 C and 85 min; PAV, 100 C, 20 h and 2.1 MPa; UV, 60 C, 6 days and the average ultraviolet radiant intensity on the asphalt surface was about 12 w/ m2.
The aging degree of all binders was assessed by some change values of rheological parameter before and after aging such as complex modulus aging index (CMAI) and phase angle aging index (PAAI) in this paper. A higher CMAI or lower PAAI means more serious aging extent. The formulated equations of CMAI and PAAI as follows:
CMAI ¼ Aged complex modulus Unaged complex modulus
ð1Þ
PAAI ¼ Aged phase angle Unaged phase angle
ð2Þ

sections.heading: 3.1. Rheological properties of SBRMA containing multi-dimensional nanomaterials
sections.text:
The rheological properties such as complex modulus (G⁄) and phase angle (d) versus temperature (30–90 C) for unmodified and modified SBRMA are shown in Fig. 1. It can be observed that SBRMAs modified by multi-dimensional nanomaterials (1% OEVMT + 1% or 2% or 3%nano-ZnO), 2%nano-ZnO and 2%OEVMT present the higher G⁄ value and the lower d value than unmodified SBRMA, nonetheless among them there is not a great deal of difference. As a result, the introducing of these nanomaterials can enhance the shear deformation resistance and elastic behavior of SBRMA. Some published researches revealed that SBR/nanoclay or SBRMA/nanoclay formed an intercalated or exfoliated microstructure, which were helpful to enhance high-temperature
performance [8–10]. So such microstructure formed by SBRMA/ OEVMT can be inferred, which is responsible for the increased G⁄ and decreased d.

sections.heading: 3.2. Thermal oxidative aging properties of SBRMA containing multidimensional nanomaterials
3.2.1. Short-term thermal oxidation aging
sections.text:
Fig. 2(a) and (b) provide data regarding the CMAI and PAAI values of unmodified and modified SBRMA after RTFOT aging, respectively. From the Fig. 2(a), it is apparent that all modified SBRMA shows the lower CMAI value than unmodified SBRMA from 30 to 90 C. Moreover, as illustrated in this Figure, when the temperature is lower than about 60 C, the SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 2%nanoZnO shows the lowest CMAI value, followed closely by the SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO. Nevertheless, when the temperature exceeds 60 C, the CMAI value of SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO is the lowest.
In addition, as shown in Fig. 2(b), the PAAI values of SBRMA modified by multi-dimensional nanomaterials are higher than that of unmodified SBRMA in the whole scanning temperature range (30–90 C). However, SBRMA with 2%nano-ZnO or 2%OEVMT shows the lower PAAI value than unmodified SBRMA at a higher temperature area. Moreover, when the temperature is less than about 45 C, the PAAI value of SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 2%nanoZnO is the highest, followed by 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO. When the temperature rises from 45 to 75 C, the PAAI value of SBRMA
with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO is the highest, while that of SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 1%nano-ZnO is the highest when the temperature exceeds 75 C.
Above results indicate that only multi-dimensional nanomaterials can effectively enhance the short-term thermal oxidative aging resistance in the whole scanning temperature range, which is owing to the formed microstructure of SBRMA/OEVMT slowed down the penetration of the oxygen molecules during aging [10,24].

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Long-term thermal oxidation aging
sections.text:
Fig. 3(a) and (b) are curve graphs which describe the trend of the CMAI and PAAI values of unmodified and modified SBRMA after PAV aging versus temperature (30–90 C), respectively. According to the Fig. 3(a), the CMAI values of all modified SBRMA are decreased remarkably with adding multi-dimensional nanomaterials, 2%nano-ZnO or 2%OEVMT compared with unmodified SBRMA. Furthermore, we can found the CMAI values of SBRMA with multidimensional nanomaterials are lower than that of SBRMA with 2% nano-ZnO or 2%OEVMT. Besides, SBRMA with 1% OEVMT + 3% nano-ZnO shows the lowest CMAI value.
In addition, the results from Fig. 3(b) shows that the PAAI values of all modified SBRMA are higher than that of unmodified SBRMA. Moreover, the modified SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO has the highest PAAI value, except that the PAAI value of SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 1%nano-ZnO is the highest when the temperature rises from 80 to 90 C. Additionally, the PAAI value of SBRMA with
SBRMA after RTFOT aging (O-OEVMT, Z-nano-ZnO).
d SBRMA after PAV aging (O-OEVMT, Z-nano-ZnO).
multi-dimensional nanomaterials is higher than that of SBRMA with 2%nano-ZnO or 2%OEVMT.
Above results demonstrate that mentioned nanomaterials can effectively improve the ability of SBRMA to resist long-term thermal oxidative aging, moreover, the improvement of 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO is the most evident. This result is also mainly attributed to the barrier action of the formed microstructure in SBRMA on oxygen molecules penetration [10,24]. Besides, compared with the results of 1%OEVMT + 1%nano-ZnO, 2%nano-ZnO and 2% OEVMT, it can be identified that the improvement of 1%OEVMT + 1%nano-ZnO is better, indicating that OEVMT and nano-ZnO compound have synergetic effect in enhancing SBRMA long-term thermal oxidative aging resistance.

sections.heading: 3.3. Photo oxidative aging properties of SBRMA containing multidimensional nanomaterials
sections.text:
Fig. 4(a) and (b) show the CMAI and PAAI value of unmodified and modified SBRMA after UV aging, respectively. As seen in Fig. 4(a), the CMAI values of modified SBRMA are lower than that of unmodified SBRMA. Moreover, SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3% nano-ZnO shows the lowest CMAI value.
In addition, as shown in Fig. 4(b), except for 2%nano-ZnO and 1% OEVMT + 2%nano-ZnO, the PAAI values of others nanomaterials modified SBRMA are higher than that of unmodified SBRMA at the whole scanning temperature range. Furthermore, SBRMA with 2%OEVMT has the highest PAAI value from 30 to 70 C, nonetheless there merely is a little difference between SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO and 2%OEVMT.
Above results illustrate that multi-dimensional nanomaterials can significantly enhance the UV aging resistance of SBRMA, which is attributed to the ability of nano-ZnO to shield and absorb UV radiation [19]. Moreover, the enhancement of 1%OEVMT + 3% nano-ZnO is the most evident.

sections.heading: 3.4. Determination of optimal proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials in SBRMA
sections.text:
Overall considering above results, we can conclude that when the OEVMT content maintains 1% by mass of base asphalt, the multi-dimensional nanomaterials containing 3%nano-ZnO by mass of base asphalt shows the best improvement in the aging resistance of SBRMA. Furthermore, in order to determine the optimal proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials in SBRMA, we continue to compare the influence of different content OEVMT (1%, 2% and 3% by mass of base asphalt) on the aging behavior of SBRMA when the nano-ZnO maintains 3% by mass of base asphalt.
Fig. 5 presents the rheological properties of unmodified and modified SBRMA after different aging methods. As shown in the Fig. 5(a) and (b), after RTFOT aging, the SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO has the lowest CMAI value and highest PAAI value. According to the Fig. 5(c) and (d), after PAV aging, the CMAI value of SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO is also the lowest, while the PAAI values of SBRMA with 1%, 2%, 3%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO show a small difference. Besides, as shown in Fig. 5(e) and (f), after UV aging, the SBRMA modified by 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO still shows the lowest CMAI value, moreover, both the PAAI values of SBRMA with 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO and 3%OEVMT + 3%nanoZnO are the highest.
Above results indicate that when the nano-ZnO content keeps at 3%, the optimal OEVMT content in enhancing aging resistance of SBRMA is 1%OEVMT. So the optimal proportion of multidimensional nanomaterials in SBRMA is 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO.

sections.heading: 3.5. Performance grade of SBRMA containing multi-dimensional nanomaterials
sections.text:
Performance grade (PG) is critical indicator evaluating the hightemperature and low-temperature performance of asphalt. In this study, it is significant to confirm the change in PG of the SBRMA after multi-dimensional nanomaterials modifying. The PG of unmodified and modified SBRMA are listed in Table 1. It can be observed that, except for 2%OEVMT and 1%OEVMT + 2%nano-ZnO, the PG of SBRMA with others proportions nanomaterials are not change, they are PG70-22. But the low temperature of the SBRMA with 2%OEVMT or 1%OEVMT + 2%nano-ZnO are found to raise by one grade from 22 to 16 C, whereas the high temperature remains unchanged.
Above results manifest that the PG of SBRMA after the optimal proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials 1%OEVMT + 3% nano-ZnO modifying maintains unchanged. However, it is also found that individual proportions of nanomaterials such as 2% OEVMT and 1%OEVMT + 2%nano-ZnO have adverse influence on the low temperature cracking resistance of SBRMA.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this paper, the influence of multi-dimensional nanomaterials on the aging rheological characteristics of SBRMAwas investigated. The main conclusions are as follows:
(1) Before aging, the addition of multi-dimensional nanomaterials can enhance the shear deformation resistance and elastic behavior of SBRMA. (2) Based on the RTFOT, PAV and UV aging test results, both thermal oxidative and photo oxidative aging resistance of SBRMA can be improved significantly with introducing multi-dimensional nanomaterials. (3) The optimal proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials in SBRMA is confirmed as 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO. Besides, the PG test result verifies that the PG of SBRMA after 1% OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO modifying maintains unchanged.

metadata.abstractText: The purpose of this work is to research the influence of multi-dimensional nanomaterials composed of surface modified nano-zinc oxide (nano-ZnO) and organic expanded vermiculite (OEVMT) on rheological characteristics of styrene butadiene rubber modified asphalt (SBRMA) before and after different aging methods. The styrene butadiene rubber modified asphalts (SBRMAs) with various proportions multidimensional nanomaterials were produced by melt blending method. All binders were aged by rolling thin film oven test (RTFOT), pressure aging vessel (PAV) and ultraviolet (UV) aging. Dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) was utilized to test the rheological properties of all samples, as well as the performance grade (PG) of all binders was checked. The results show that the addition of multi-dimensional nanomaterials can enhance the shear deformation resistance and elastic behavior of SBRMA. Based on the RTFOT, PAV and UV aging test results, both thermal oxidative and photo oxidative aging resistance of SBRMA can be improved significantly by introducing multi-dimensional nanomaterials. Moreover, the optimal proportion of multi-dimensional nanomaterials in SBRMA is confirmed as 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO. Besides, the PG test result verifies that the PG of SBRMA after 1%OEVMT + 3%nano-ZnO modifying maintains unchanged. 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
